_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



VWR International, headquartered in Radnor, Pennsylvania, is a global laboratory supply and distribution company.  VWR is ready to support your production facility with reliable access to raw materials and essential supplies; provide innovative, high quality products for life science labs; provide products and processes in the healthcare industry; supply enhanced access to over 100,000 Safety & Industrial Supplies; provide a selected portfolio specifically designed to help prevent potential contamination and maintain aseptic conditions in cleanrooms and controlled environments; provide lab furniture; and provide comprehensive information and services on chromatography instruments, software, and consumables for a wide variety of chromatography techniques and applications. 



The VWR International management is not only committed to offering superior supplies and services, but also to maintaining a safety and environmental program to promote a safe environment for all its employees and the surrounding communities.  VWR International's safety and environmental policies are administered by the Distribution Manager with the assistance from the Regulatory Affairs and Environmental Health & Safety Manager, who all conduct periodic inspections of the facility to ensure compliance, and will oversee the entire safety and environmental programs, including the CalARP Program. 



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The VWR International facility is located at 8711 Riggin Avenue in Visalia, California, which is located approximately 2.5 miles east of CA Highway 99 and 2 miles north of CA Highway 198.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is rural with primarily agricultural areas and a mixture of commercial, industrial, and residential areas.  The facility was constructed and began operations in July 2012.



The primary business of VWR International is a chemical storage/distribution facility.

The regulated substances of concern are: chloroform, ethyl ether, hydrogen fluoride, and nitric acid.   These chemicals are stored in containers of varying s, the largest storage container is listed below.  The containers are delivered by freight companies, which will remain onsite until they are purchased by a customer, at which point they are picked up for delivery to the client.  The containers are transported by forklift or pallet jacks to/from the delivery trucks.



Chloroform, 55 gallon - Health Hazards / Corrosives Room

Ethyl Ether, 55 gallon - Flammable Storage Area

Hydrogen Fluoride 48-52%, 50 gallon - Health Hazards / Corrosives Room

Nitric Acid 7%, 5 gallon - Oxidizers Room

* The chemicals are stored in various container s. The list above shows the largest storage container for each chemical.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



In order to operate the storage and distribution facility, VWR International complies with the CalEMA California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed. 



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



As this facility began operations in July 2012, there have been no significant releases of any regulated chemicals that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantities stated below,

 

Chloroform - 10 lbs.

Ethyl Ether - 100 lbs.

Hydrogen Fluoride - 100 lbs.

Nitric Acid - 1,000 lbs.



or the state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material in the past five years (July 2007 - July 2012).  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a chemical release, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility has an Integrated Prevention and Response Plan (IPRP), which includes an Emergency Response Plan (plan) as required by t

tems, including the recommendations, prior to start up, as an effort to provide a safe work environment for their employees.  These changes include the following items:

 

1. Continue to train all employees in the facility Safety Plan/Programs.



2. Continue to have employee involvement in Safety Plan Development.



3. Continue employee involvement through safety team participation.



4. Continue internal and external safety audits/inspections and implement changes as needed.



Recommendation tracking for the technical studies will be maintained onsite at the facility.
